questions.text: As per WHO 2017 Global Recommendation, the latest addition to the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage is:

choices.text: Late cord clamping is recommended for all births
Oxytocin 10 U IV/IM is the recommended uterotonic drug in the prevention of PPH
Intravenous oxytocin alone is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH
Early use of intravenous tranexamic acid is recommended in all cases of PPH

questions.solution:
The latest update in treatment of Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) as per WHO 2017 Global recommendations is the early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (a competitive inhibitor of plasminogen activation) is recommended in all cases of PPH.

PPH is the leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide and in India.

WHO 2012 recommendations included a conditional recommendation to use TXA for treatment of PPH when uterotonics fail to control the bleeding or the bleeding is thought to be due to trauma.

In 2017, WHO updated its 2012 PPH treatment recommendations to include use of TXA for treatment of PPH.

WHO 2017 Global Recommendation, latest addition to the treatment of PPH:

  • Early use of intravenous tranexamic acid (TXA) within 3 hours of birth for women with clinically diagnosed postpartum haemorrhage (PPH).
  • TXA should be used in all cases of PPH, regardless of the cause.
  • TXA should be administered at a fixed dose of 1 g in 10 mL (100 mg/mL) IV at 1 mL per minute (i.e., administered over 10 minutes), with a second dose of 1 g IV if bleeding continues after 30 minutes.
  • TXA should be administered via an IV route only for treatment of PPH.

WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of postpartum haemorrhage (2012)

  • Oxytocin (10 IU, IV/IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH.
  • Intravenous oxytocin alone is the recommended uterotonic drug for the treatment of PPH.
  • If oxytocin is unavailable, other injectable uterotonics (ergometrine/methylergometrine or the fixed drug combination of oxytocin and ergometrine) or oral misoprostol (600 µg) is recommended.
  • Late cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births.
  • Controlled cord traction is the recommended method for removal of the placenta in caesarean section.

In 2017, the results of World Maternal Antifibrinolytic Trial showed that early use of IV TXA (within 3 hours of birth and as soon as possible after onset of bleeding) reduces death due to bleeding in women with PPH, regardless of cause, and with no adverse maternal effects. In response to this new evidence, WHO updated its 2012 PPH treatment recommendations to include use of TXA for treatment of PPH. This recommendation supersedes the recommendation on TXA in the existing 2012 WHO recommendations for the prevention and treatment of PPH. The goals of the WHO 2017 recommendation on TXA for PPH treatment are to improve the quality of care for women with PPH and prevent maternal deaths due to PPH

Recent Update: In 2020, the WHO issued a guideline which recommends the preference of IV oxytocin over IM oxytocin for the prevention of PPH, in situations where women giving birth vaginally already have IV access. This recomendation supercedes its 2012 recommendation for the prevention of PPH.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is currently approved for the treatment of small pox?
questions.solution:
Tecovirimat has been recently approved as a treatment of smallpox.

It was approved under the FDA's animal rule, which allows findings from animal studies to support an FDA approval when it is not feasible or ethical to conduct efficacy trials in humans. Cidofovir has also been approved by the FDA for smallpox under this rule.

Both these drugs are currently stockpiled by CDC’s strategic national stockpile, which has the medical supplies required to protect the public in case of a public health emergency.

Tecovirimat could also be used under an investigational new drug (IND) protocol to treat adverse reactions from vaccinia vaccination.

Option B: Lumacaftor is a drug approved for cystic fibrosis.

Option C: Pegvaliase has been approved for the treatment of phenylketonuria in adults.

Option D: Apalutamide is a nonsteroidal antiandrogen medication which is used in the treatment of prostate cancer. It is specifically indicated for use in conjunction with castration in the treatment of non-metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.

questions.text: Histopathological findings of a lung tumor biopsy are shown below. Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific marker of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given image shows keratin pearls and islands of large polygonal malignant cells. These as seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the lungs. P40 is the most sensitive and specific marker for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lungs.

Other markers include cytokeratin 5/6 and P63.

TTF-1 and napsin-A are the markers for adenocarcinoma.

Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

Note: The 2015 World Health Organization Classification of Lung Tumors has made a recommendation that at least one antibody each for squamous (P40 or P63) and glandular (e.g. TTF-1) differentiation should be used for an initial workup. Thus a simple panel of TTF-1 and p40 may be able to classify most non-small cell carcinoma-not otherwise specified cases.

questions.text: According to ESC 2018 guidelines, blood pressure is classified as high normal if ______ (mmHg)
questions.solution: According to ESC guidelines, blood pressure is classified as high normal if SBP 130-139 mmHg and DBP 85-89 mmHg.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023 by WHO?

choices.text: Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection
Separation of polio surveillance and vaccine preventable disease surveillance
Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)

questions.solution:
Integration, not separation, of polio surveillance with vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) surveillance, is a part of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023.

Goals of the Polio Endgame Strategy 2019–2023

Goal One: Eradication

  • Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)
  • Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection and eliminate the risk of emergence of future VDPVs

Goal two: Integration

  • Contribute to strengthening immunization and health systems to help achieve and sustain polio eradication
  • Ensure sensitive poliovirus surveillance through integration with comprehensive vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) and communicable disease surveillance systems
  • Prepare for and respond to future outbreaks and emergencies

Goal Three: Certification & Containment

  • Certify eradication of WPV
  • Contain all polioviruses

questions.text: Which monoclonal antibody is approved for use in HIV-1?
questions.solution:
Ibalizumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for use in the treatment of resistant HIV-1 infections. 

Ibalizumab blocks HIV-1 from infecting CD4+ T cells by binding to domain 2 of CD4 cells. It also interferes with post-attachment steps required for the entry of HIV-1 virus particles into host cells and thus prevents the viral transmission that occurs via cell-cell fusion.

Option A: Ixekizumab is an IL-17A antagonist indicated in moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. 

Option C: Idarucizumab is a reversal agent for dabigatran.

Option D: Ipilimumab is a monoclonal antibody against CTLA-4 and acts as an immune checkpoint inhibitor.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis has inadequate disease control with methotrexate. Which Janus kinase inhibitor can you add to his treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Baricitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor approved for use in rheumatoid arthritis. 

Oral Janus kinase inhibitors for rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Baricitinib 
  • Tofacitinib 

Option A: Ruxolitinib is a Janus kinase inhibitor approved for use in various forms of myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera and acute graft vs host disease.

Options C and D: Dasatinib and ponatinib are BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitors indicated for CML. 

In November 2020, the U.S. FDA issued an emergency use authorization (EUA) for baricitinib in combination with remdesivir, for the treatment of suspected or lab-confirmed COVID-19 in hospitalized adults and children two years of age or older requiring supplemental oxygen, invasive mechanical ventilation, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

questions.text: Nonpeptide oral GnRH antagonist that is recently approved for endometriosis treatment is:
questions.solution:
A new agent, elagolix sodium (orilissa), is a nonpeptide oral GnRH antagonist that is recently approved by FDA for the management of moderate to severe pain associated with endometriosis.

  • GnRH antagonists, cetrorelix and ganirelix, are currently FDA approved for infertility use in women undergoing controlled ovarian hyperstimulation
  • However, a limitation of these drugs is that they are daily injectables. Also, a depot form of cetrorelix did not provide adequate or consistent suppression of estrogen production or leiomyoma growth.

questions.text: The only FDA approved drug for primary progressive multiple sclerosis is _________.
questions.solution:
Ocrelizumab is the only FDA approved drug (2017) for the treatment of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS)

  • Natalizumab is FDA approved for the treatment of relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and Crohn’s disease. It increases the risk of Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy(PML).
  • Alemtuzumab is also FDA approved for relapsing forms of MS. It contains a black box warning for serious fatal autoimmune conditions.
  • Glatimer acetate is found to be effective in RRMS.

Treatment of multiple sclerosis:

  • Glucocorticoids are used to manage either first attacks or acute exacerbations. Intravenous methylprednisolone, 500–1000 mg/d for 3–5 days, followed by a course of oral prednisone beginning at a dose of 60–80 mg/d and gradually tapered over 2 weeks is given. They reduce the severity and shorten the duration of attacks.
  • Disease modifying therapies for relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis are:
    1. IFN-β-1a (Avonex)
    2. IFN-β-1a (Rebif)
    3. IFN-β-1b (Betaseron or Extavia)
    4. Glatiramer acetate
    5. Natalizumab
    6. Fingolimod
    7. Dimethyl fumarate
    8. Teriflunomide
    9. Mitoxantrone
    10. Alemtuzumab

questions.text: The most effective bariatric surgery for morbid obesity among  the following options is:
questions.solution:
The most effective bariatric surgery for morbid obesity among the following options is biliopancreatic diversion.

Following table represents Malabsorption,percent excess weight loss and diabetic remission after various bariartic surgery:

  Protein/calorie  malabsorption 3year %EWL 3year%diabetes remission
Gastric band No 40-50% 20%
Gastric bypass No 50-60% 50%
Sleeve gastrectomy No 50-60% 50%
Bilio pancreatic diversion/Duodenal switch Yes 70-80% 80%

%EWL =Excess weight lost above a notional upper normal BMI of 25.

Laproscopic adjustable gastric banding is the safest and reversible bariatric surgery.

Bariatric surgery:

Indications:

  • Patients with BMI greater than equal to 40kg/m2 regardless of comorbidity.
  • Patients with BMI greater or equal to 35 kg/m2 with comorbidity.

     Restrictive  Bariatric surgeries

    • Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding
    • Laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy

    • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass - M/C bypass procedure(Largely restrictive/Mildly malabsorptive)
    • Biliopancreatic diversion(Largely malabsorptive /Mildly restrictive)
    • Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (Largely malabsorptive /Mildly restrictive)

 

 

Metabolic surgery refers to the marked effects of some operations on diabetes and the metabolic syndrome (including high blood pressure, dyslipidaemia and polycystic ovary syndrome), which may have an impact more important than weight loss itself.

The improvement in type 2 diabetes may be additional to the weight loss

Surgery is very cost effective since medications can be reduced or stopped once the glycaemic control improves post operatively.

questions.text: According to the Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for grading the severity of acute cholecystitis, which of the following conditions is classified under moderate (Grade II) acute cholecystitis?
questions.solution:
If the duration of complaints is >72 hours, the patient is classified as having moderate (Grade II) acute cholecystitis.

Tokyo Consensus Guidelines for grading the severity of acute cholecystitis
Grade III (severe) acute cholecystitis
Associated with organ dysfunction
1. Cardiovascular dysfunction Hypotension* requiring treatment with dopamine >5 mcg/kg/min, or any dose of noradrenaline
2. Neurological dysfunction Decreased level of consciousness
3. Respiratory dysfunction PaO2/FiO2 ratio <300
4. Renal dysfunction Oliguria; serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
5. Hepatic dysfunction Prothrombin time (PT-INR)>1.5
6. Hematological dysfunction  Platelet count, <100,000/mm3
Grade II (moderate) acute cholecystitis

Associated with dysfunction of any one of the following:

  1. Elevated white blood cell count (>18,000/mm3)
  2. Palpable tender mass in the right upper abdominal quadrant
  3. Duration of complaints >72 hours
  4. Marked local inflammation (gangrenous cholecystitis, pericholecystic abscess, hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis)
Grade I (mild) acute cholecystitis 

Does not meet the criteria of grade II or III acute cholecystitis.

Acute cholecystitis in a healthy person with no organ dysfunction and mild inflammatory changes in the gall bladder, making cholecystectomy a safe and low-risk operative procedure.


Acute cholecystitis is treated by keeping the patient nil per oral (NPO), administering intravenous fluids, analgesics, and IV antibiotics.

The timing of surgery in acute cholecystitis remains controversial:

  • If the patient presents within 3 days, emergency cholecystectomy is done.
  • If the patient presents after 3 days, conservative management is done initially. Once the inflammation subsides, cholecystectomy is performed after 6 weeks (interval cholecystectomy).

Recent edition update: *In the 27th edition of Bailey and Love, it is incorrectly mentioned that the cardiovascular dysfunction is hypertension requiring dopamine ≤5 mcg/kg/min.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017?

choices.text: Advance directive rights of the mentally ill
Procedure for admission, treatment and discharge of the mentally ill

questions.solution:
Establishing mobile mental health camps for the benefit of mentally ill patients is not included under the Mental Healthcare Act of 2017.

This act encourages the mobilization of resources to improve mental health care across the country as well as reduce stigma and improve social inclusion/support for those with mental illness. It also has provisions to improve outcomes and protect their rights.

The provisions of this act include:

  • Rights of persons with mental illness to access health care, live without discrimination and enjoy confidentiality.
  • Advance directives to allow mentally ill people to make decisions about their treatment 
  • Procedures for admission, treatment (behavioral and interpersonal therapy, medications), and discharge 
  • Decriminalizing suicide and prohibiting electroconvulsive therapy unless anesthesia is used

The act also has clear instructions for the central and state mental health authorities and other mental health establishments on their endeavors.

questions.text: The percentage of immature erythroid precursors required to diagnose pure erythroid leukaemia is _________.
questions.solution:
Pure erythroid leukemia or acute myeloid leukemia (AML) NOS, acute erythroid leukemia can be diagnosed if >80% of the bone marrow cells are erythroid, with >=30% proerythroblasts and no evidence of a significant myeloblastic component.

Previously, cases were classified as erythroleukemia (erythroid/myeloid type) on the basis of counting myeloblasts as a percentage of non-erythroid cells when erythroid precursor cells constituted >50% of the marrow cells.

Such cases are now classified as

  • MDS with excess blasts, if myeloblasts constitute <20% of all marrow or blood cells
  • Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with myelodysplasia-related changes, if myeloblasts constitute >=20% of the cells, irrespective of the erythroid precursor cell count.

Note: AML with myelodysplasia-related changes requires >20% myeloblasts, whereas the neoplastic cells in pure erythroid leukaemia are erythroblasts.

Recent update: The above information is based on 4th edition of the WHO classification of hematopoeitic and lymphoid tumors, which is a joint project of the European Association for Haematopathology and the Society of Hematopathology. 

Acute erythroid leukemia is also called Di Guglielmo syndrome

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl has just started menstruating. Under which of the following national programmes, she will be provided with a pack of sanitary napkins by the ASHA worker in her village?
questions.solution:
The girl will be provided with a pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA worker through the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme under the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK).

RKSK focuses on:

  • Development of adolescent population (10-19 years).
  • Weekly Iron and Folic Acid supplementation (100mg Fe + 500 mcg Folic Acid)
  • Menstrual hygiene: A pack of 6 sanitary napkins for 6 Rupees (called Freedays) by the ASHA.
  • It also includes enhancement of mental health and prevention of substance abuse and violence.

Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana is a government-sponsored savings program for parents of girl children <10 years age. It helps parents to set aside money for their female child’s potential college and marriage expenses by opening an account at any post office branch or any commercial bank approved by the central government.

Kishori Shakti Yojana (KSY) seeks to empower adolescent girls, so as to enable them to take charge of their lives. The objectives are to:

  • improve the nutritional, health and development status of adolescent girls
  • promote awareness of health, hygiene, nutrition and family care
  • opportunities for learning life skills
  • going back to school
  • help them gain a better understanding of their social environment
  • take initiatives to become productive members of society.

Recent update: Department of Pharmaceuticals under Ministry of Chemicals and Fertilizers has recently launched ‘Suvidha’ (100% Oxo-biodegradable Sanitary Napkin), under the Pradhan Mantri Bhartiya Janaushadhi Pariyojana (PMBJP) on World menstrual hygiene day. ‘Swachhta, Swasthya and Suvidha’ will be available for Rs. 1 per pad over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendras for the underprivileged women of India.

National Girl child day is observed on January 24th annually to raise awareness about the issues and challenges faced by the girl children in India and promote their rights and empowerment by eliminating gender biases, and emphasise the importance of education, health, and nutrition.

questions.text: What is the fluid requirement of a 50 kg man with first degree burns to his left arm and leg, circumferential second degree burns to his right upper limb and third degree burns to his posterior torso and right lower limb. What is the rate of initial fluid resuscitation?

choices.text: 2.25L over 8 hours, followed by 2.25L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
Total volume of fluid needed is 4.5 litres of which 2.25L is given in first 8 hours and 2.25L is given in next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating % of burns using rule of nines

  • This includes only 2nd and 3rd degree burns.
  • Right upper limb + right lower limb and posterior torso = 9 + 18 + 18 = 45%

STEP 2 : Calculating fluid using resucitation formula for thermal burns - 2ml x 50(kg) x 45(TBSA%) = 4.5 litres.

 

Note:

According to new ATLS 10th ed 2018 guidelines, the resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2ml/kg/TBSA%. The fluid requirement during the initial 24 hours of treatment is 2 mL/kg of body weight for each percent of TBSA burned, given IV. Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation. One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first eight hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours. The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: The nanny of a 3-year-old boy brings the child to the ER after he had accidentally ingested button batteries from the mobile phone toy that he was playing with. What would be the next best step in the management of this child?

choices.text: Observation and follow up in 24 hours
Observation until the foreign body passes out in faeces

questions.solution:
Button batteries and sharp objects in the oesophagus and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms all mandate urgent endoscopic removal.

Button batteries, in particular, are very dangerous foreign bodies, which must be expediently removed because they can cause:

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the oesophagus in 4 hours

Injury is thought to be secondary to electrochemical burns from electrical discharge. Chemical burns from electrolyte alkali leakage and pressure necrosis also may contribute to mucosal injury.

Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the oesophagus can be observed for up to 24 hr in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

This recent AIIMS question was based on a study conducted in 2018 that demonstrated, early and frequent ingestion of honey in the crucial period between ingestion of the button battery and endoscopic removal can reduce the injury caused and improve patient outcome.

questions.text:
Which among the following best describes sepsis?

SOFA - Sepsis-related Organ Failure Assessment

qSOFA - quick Sepsis-related Organ dysfunction Assessment

LODS - The Logistic Organ Dysfunction System score

SIRS - Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome score

choices.text: Suspected or documented infection with SIRS score ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score  ≥ 1
Suspected or documented infection with LODS score ≥ 1

questions.solution:
Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 best describes sepsis among the given options.

Sepsis is defined as, life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.

To help in recognizing sepsis, Sepsis-3 clinical criteria have been used, which include:

  • Suspected infection  
  • Organ dysfunction which is assessed using the SOFA score - an increase of ≥ 2 points from the baseline of this score 

SOFA score ranges from 0 to 24 points and is divided across 6 organ systems. It includes:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

A simplified version of the SOFA score is known as the qSOFA score (Option C). It includes:

  • Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min
  • Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

  • SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is considered superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.
  • qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thus, the best description of sepsis would be :

  • Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2
    OR
  • Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

Other scoring systems for sepsis:

Option A:

Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) is an exaggerated defence response of the body to a noxious stressor to localize and then eliminate the endogenous or exogenous source of the insult. SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (>38 Degree Celcius) or Hypothermia (<36 Degree Celcius)
  • Tachypnoea (>20/min) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) of less than 32 mm Hg
  • Tachycardia (>90/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/litre or <4 x 109/litre or >10% Band forms

 Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection. SIRS score is no longer recommended as is it not specific to infection.

Option D: LODS score is not recommended as it is complex and has too many variables.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented to the CHC with fever and chills for the past 2 days. His peripheral blood smear is given. Treatment was started with chloroquine. Which of the following drugs can you prescribe to prevent relapse in him?
questions.solution:
Tafenoquine can be prescribed to prevent relapse in the patient. The given clinical features and the image containing Plasmodium vivax trophozoites point toward a diagnosis of malaria. Tafenoquine can be used for the prevention of relapse of Plasmodium vivax malaria in patients who are 16 years or older. It has been recently approved for the radical cure of plasmodium vivax malaria. It is not indicated in acute infection.

Option C: Ivacaftor is a cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) potentiator, that is used for the treatment of cystic fibrosis (CF) in patients age 2 years and older.

Option D: Ibalizumab is a CD4 directed HIV-1 inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant HIV infection.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for the initial episode of non severe Clostridium difficile colitis is :
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for the initial episode of non-severe Clostridium difficile colitis is oral fidaxomicin. 

Management of Clostridium difficile infection according to SHEA and IDSA 2021 guidelines
 Nonfulminant  disease- Initial episode  Oral fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin
 Nonfulminant  disease- recurrent episode  Oral fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin
Bezlotoxumab can be used as an adjunctive
 Fulminant disease (presence of hypotension, shock, megacolon) without ileus  Oral vancomycin plus intravenous metronidazole 
 Fulminant disease (presence of hypotension, shock, megacolon) with ileus  Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) or rectal vancomycin

Fidaxomicin is preferred over oral vancomycin because it has less relapse rates.

questions.text: Which of the following is a WHO-approved dengue vaccine for individuals seropositive for dengue virus?
questions.solution:
Dengvaxia is a WHO-approved vaccine for individuals seropositive for dengue virus. It is currently licensed in 20 countries.

A pre-vaccination screening strategy must be adopted so that only dengue-seropositive individuals are vaccinated. It is indicated for individuals between 9 to 16 years. It is given in 3 doses, 6 months apart. Booster doses are not required.

However, it carries an increased risk of severe dengue in those who experience their first natural dengue infection after vaccination (seronegative individuals).

Note: TV003, a live, attenuated, tetravalent dengue vaccine is currently in Phase-3 trials. It has shown efficacy in promoting immunity in both seropositive and seronegative individuals between 2-59 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission?

choices.text: Government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year
The limit of the family size that is covered is up to 7 members
All pre-existing diseases of the individual are covered
It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization

questions.solution:
There is no cap on family size or the age of the members. All the families listed under the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database are covered as per the defined criteria.

The following are the benefits provided under this program:

  • Health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the SECC database, as per the defined criteria, will be covered. There is no cap on family size and age of members.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals
  • Both secondary and tertiary care hospitalization is covered.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • To control costs, the payments for treatment will be done on a package rate (to be defined by the Government in advance) basis.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and abnormal flexion?
questions.solution:
The GCS score is E2VNTM3. In this case:

  • Eye-opening to pain: E2
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as 'not testable/NT'. Earlier in intubated patients, the V score was denoted as VT. According to the current update, the V score should be VNT.
  • Abnormal flexion: M3

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD, with a 7cm lesion over the left buccal mucosa and difficulty opening the mouth. On examination, the right cervical lymph node is 4cm in size with overlying skin involvement. What is the TNM staging of this lesion?
questions.solution:
The TNM staging in this patient is T4bN3bMX. A 7-cm primary tumor in the oral cavity with difficulty in opening mouth denotes a locally advanced tumor: T4b. Contralateral cervical lymph node involvement with skin involvement (extranodal extension-positive): N3b

Note: Here the skin invasion corresponds to ENE positive, and hence, the N staging is N3b instead of N2c (contralateral lymph nodes, <6 cm and ENE‐negative).

questions.text: An unmarried man had consensual sexual intercourse with the wife of his friend. His friend found about the affair and filed an FIR against the man. Under which of the following BNS section can the man be booked?
questions.solution:
Adultery is not liable for criminal prosecution.

Section 497 of the Indian Penal Code dealing with adultery was invalidated (struck down as unconstitutional being violative of articles 14 and 21) by the Hon’ble Supreme Court of India on 27th September 2018. However, there might be civil liabilities including ground for divorce and dissolution of marriage.

However, BNS retains Section 498 of the IPC as BNS Section 84 which penalizes a man for enticing the wife of another man so that she may have intercourse with any person. 

Option A: BNS 318(4)/IPC 420 deals with cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property.

Option B: BNS 75/IPC 354A deals with sexual harassment and punishment of sexual harassment. Consensual sexual intercourse is not included in this.
